meanings.definition: To date (an event or document) with a date earlier than the actual date.
meanings.sent1: She foredated the letter to make it seem like it was written earlier.
meanings.sent2: The historian discovered that the signature on the document was foredated.
meanings.sent3: The detective joked that the suspect must have foredated their alibi.
meanings.sent4: His prediction foredated the actual occurrence of the event.
meanings.sent5: The artist's sketch foredated the completion of the masterpiece.

meanings.sent1: The morning sun foredated the arrival of the storm.
meanings.sent2: The ancient ruins foredated the modern city by centuries.
meanings.sent3: The teacher playfully claimed that the homework foredated the invention of pencils.
meanings.sent4: Her wisdom foredated her years, making her an old soul.
meanings.sent5: The sound of the bell foredated the start of the race, causing excitement among the participants.
